p: In the Southwestern Atlantic, coastal reef communities occur along of 3000 km of the Brazilian coastline [ 13], showing high endemism of reef-building species [ 14]. Four of those endemic species belong to the genus Mussismilia, commonly known as brain-corals [ 15, 16, 17]. Although molecular assessments on Mussismilia are still rare [ 18], the distinctiveness among species is well established, allowing rapid identification in the field [ 15]. The genus has at least two species in risk of extinction: M. braziliensis and M. harttii [ 19]. The first is restricted to shallow reefs of Bahia State and Abrolhos reefs, whereas the latter is found from the coast of Ceará to Espírito Santo States (from -3.822 to -18.0480 latitude).
